div3.head: From the army of Northern Virginia.
div3.p:
--Passengers by the Central train last evening brought nothing of interest from Gen. Lee's army.
Observations taken by the Signal Corps on Monday morning discovered in the direction of Warrenton Springs a large fire, but it was not known from what cause it proceeded.

div3.head: From Tennessee.
div3.p:
--The only reliable information received from this quarter yesterday was a dispatch stating that the enemy was concentrating at some point in the neighborhood of Knoxville, and that the grand battle could not be much longer deferred.
Ample preparations have been made on our side to meet any emergency, and we only await the beginning of the conflict to look for success to our arms.

div3.head: The contest for Commissioner of the Board of Public Works.
div3.p:
--An election was held in May last for a Commissioner of the Board of Public Works, Mr. Benjamin F. Beall, of Jefferson county, and Mr. Geo. W. Murphy, of Shenandoah, receiving the highest number of votes cast.
There being some informality in the returns of Mr. Murphy, the Governor awarded the election to Mr. Beall.
and he had entered upon the duties of the office.
Mr. Murphy carried the case before the Court of Appeals, and yesterday that body gave its decision, which reverses the action of the Governor, and pronounces in favor of Mr. M. It appears that the admission of the refugee vote for this office was considered invalid by the Court, and in their opinion Mr. B. all only received one vote, and that was cast in Shenandoah.
The opinion of the Judges, we learn, was unanimous.

div3.head: Our army correspondence.
div3.p:
The gallant and ubiquitous Mosby has returned from the war path, but this time received his furlough, in the shape of two flesh wounds in the right thigh and side.
Fortunately for the service they are not dangerous, and will cause only a temporary absence from the field.
He again penetrated near Alexandria, capturing his usual quota of prisoners, &c., and losing one man killed and two wounded in a fight on Thursday last.

Our cavalry under Gen. Stuart, at the immediate front have nothing to vary the monotony of their vigils save the picking up of isolated parties of Yankees now and then, who are consigned at once to the hospitalities of Captain Turner, of the "Libby," at Richmond. --General Stuart is watching the enemy with unceasing vigilance, and his men never fail to give the enemy a trial of their mettle when the chance is presented.
Notwithstanding the evident reaction in Gen. Stuart's favor, great injustice is yet done him by those who know nothing experimentally of any branch of the service, especially that of which he is chief in this army.
Without assuming to be a judge, I venture to say that when the difficulties, past and present, of his position are duly weighed, it will be found that the balance is largely to his credit, and that the country owes him a debt of gratitude not easily repaid.

According to all the information of Meade's army, he has no present intention or disposition to advance.
He is now in position to protect Washington if threatened, and such reasonably appears to be his programme for the season.
Should Gen. Lee determine to turn assailant again, Meade could probably reach the Potomac before we could overtake him. The signs, in my humble judgment, are that the prevailing calm is not that which is usually the precursor of the storm.
A deserter represents that considerable disaffection and desertions have been produced in the Yankee army by the late accession of a few regiments of contrabands — especially among the troops from the border States, who find it is not the feast to which they were invited.
Let us hope that, as the negrophilists broke up the Union for war, they will yet prove the rock on which they and their allies will split, and our enemies be as a house divided against itself.

Col. C. A. Battle, of the 3d Ala. regiment, Rodes's brigade, who first entered the service as a private, received his commission Friday as Brigadier-General, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the promotion of Major-General Rodes at Chancellorsville.
I subjoin the following addresses, issued on the assumption of his new sphere of duty;

div4.opener:
Headq's Battle's Brigade,
August 29, 1863. To the Third Alabama:
Soldiers
div4.p:
--When the war cloud first appeared in our Southern sky the 3d Alabama regiment unfurled its flag and prepared for the conflict.
Its soldiery came from the plains of the interior and the waters of the Gulf.
A stranger to the most of you, your unsolicited suffrages conferred upon me the rank of Major.
Day after day has teemed with evidences of your generous confidence.
In the various positions of Major, Lieut. Colonel, and Colonel, I have leaned on your strong arms for support, and now turn to you in grateful acknowledgments of the new born honors I this day wear.
It is a matter of unaffected gratification to me, and is just ground of congratulation to you, that I am succeeded by an officer of high ability and lofty patriotism, who blends most harmoniously the sterling qualities of the soldier and the mild courtesies of the gentleman.--With such field officers as Col. Forsythe, Lieut. Col. Sands, and Major Powell, the 3d Alabama regiment will certainly sustain its reputation, and may rise to a position not hitherto attained.
div4.closer:
Yours, sincerely,
Cullen A. Battle,
Brigadier General.

div4.p:
--Your signal valor on the most sanguinary fields of the revolution has reflected the highest honor on your State, and has shed unfading glory on the Confederate flag.
However brilliant the past has been, or however promising is the present, the future will determine the place your are to fill in the hearts of your countrymen and in the history of the times.
The foe that you have so often defeated is again massing his columns in your front.
With an humble trust in that God who has so often given us the victory, let us move forward when the hour of destiny comes to the deliverance of our land.
Proud of my command, it shall be my ambition to defend its rights, maintain its honor, and perpetuate its fame.

The General was complimented with a serenade Saturday night, and, being a fine declaimer, spoke feelingly and appropriately.
Hon. Wm. G. Jones, Judge of the Confederate Court of Mobile, also addressed the soldiers, and gave a most encouraging account of the tone of public sentiment in that city and Alabama.

Among the various arms of the service now being recruited under the President's late call on the reserve conscripts, steps have been taken to raise and organize a regiment of Engineer troops, including two companies of Pontooniers.
This is a corps much needed in this army, and it is the first attempt, I believe, that has been made to supply the demand.
The officers charged with the duty are efficient, and from ocular evidence at various times during the recent march to and from Pennsylvania such a regiment will be of great practical service in an active campaign, and is a necessary adjunct of a well appointed army.

The Medical Director of Ewell's corps, a successful surgeon and practitioner, has discovered by frequent trial that honey, applied by a light brush or other convenient means of the kind, is a most effectual remedy to prevent fly-blows in wounds.
It is at the same time very soothing and grateful to the wounded part; and as this question has been often discussed during the war hospital nurses and those entrusted with the care of the wounded soldier, should preserve the recollection of this simple and convenient remedy. * *

div3.head:
[correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch]
an army incident.
div3.p:
Many stirring incidents take place along the lines of this army which are suffered to pass away from memory for want of a chronicler.
This ought not so to be, as the future historian may derive from them important assistance in forming an accurate idea of this great contest, and the matchless courage of the men of the South.

I heard yesterday an incident which deserves to be put on record.
When General Stuart commenced his march to Pennsylvania, by way of Manassas, about the 24th of June, he had a fight with a body of the enemy's cavalry at Glasscock's Gap, in the Bull Run Mountain, near.
Thoroughfare, and drove them off. About twenty prisoners were taken, and as the road was thought to be clear they were ordered to be taken to the rear, in the direction of Culpeper C. H.--Lieut. Saussy, of the Jeff.
Davis Legion, was put in charge of them, with a detail of four men to serve as a guard.
The Lieutenant proceeded with his prisoners by Little Baltimore in the direction of Warrenton, supposing that the way was entirely clear; but after proceeding some distance was met by a scouting party who informed him that they had just run against a regiment of Yankee cavalry in the fog which prevailed and nearly been captured.
Having given him this information they proceeded on their way.

Instead of turning back, Lieut. Saussy determined to see for himself, and not change his route unless compelled to do so. He marched his prisoners to the woods, by the side of the road, and ordering them to lie down on their faces in a dry ditch, put two of his men in charge, directing them to run their sabres through the first man who turned over even.
With the two other men, he then went in the direction of the enemy and dismounting, proceeded on foot and came on their column drawn up in the road.--Creeping through the undergrowth until he and his two men were close on the Yankees, he suddenly opened fire on them with a loud shout to an imaginary squadron to "Charge the Rascals!"

The effect was instantaneous.
The enemy were thrown into entire disorder, and scattered in every direction, leaving the Lieutenant in possession of the field.
He then marched his prisoners to Warrenton, crossed the Rappahannock, and delivered them to the Provost Marshal at Culpeper C. H.
As he was leaving them, a Captain of the party, said, with concentrated venom: "I hope we will meet again in this war, sir."
"I hope we will," was the Confederate Lieutenant's reply, "but your won't see any thing like this."
"Like what?"
"Why, five of your men taking twenty Confederates to the rear, and driving off a regiment of our men on the road!"
I don't think the Yankee Captain made much "by his motion." Do you, Mr. Editor?

div3.head: Programme of the Lincoln Government.
div3.p:
--Complete Subjugation and Confiscation Determined On.--Much has been said and written by both Southern and Northern citizens about the recent Cabinet meeting in Washington, upon the question of the differences between the sections and the basis of a reconstruction.
In this meeting Seward was reported to favor what he styles a liberal and conciliatory policy — the recall of the emancipation proclamation, and the guarantee of the rights of property to Southern rebels, while Lincoln and his adherents clung to the proclamation and confiscation laws.
The Jackson Mississippian has information of a reliable character on the subject, from a gentleman lately from Kentucky and well posted.
It says:

q.p:
A delegation of prominent Kentucky Unionists went to Washington and sought an interview with Lincoln's Cabinet, to lay before it a plan for peace upon the basis of reconstruction.
In the discussion on the subject Lincoln and Seward, and, indeed, the whole Cabinet, took the ground that a war with Europe was inevitable, after the suppression of the rebellion, regarding the accomplishment of the latter little job as a foregone conclusion.

div3.p:
Seward was rather disposed to favor the plan proposed by the Kentucky Reconstructionists, and argued that in view of the after claps — the war with England and France.--the policy of the United States was to conciliate the South, and receive assistance in that war from the border States at least, and perhaps from a large portion of the whole Southern people, in whose bosoms a latent love for the Union still existed, and would burn brightly if a magnanimous and liberal policy prevailed with the Government.
He gave it as his opinion that this was the true way to save the North from the power of European armies.

Mr. Lincoln disagreed with him. He feared that no leniency would make the rebels loyal to his Government, and whatever treaties they might be willing to make, now that their armies were in a fair way of being crushed out, they would not do to trust in a foreign war. They would not be bound by treaties, and when a European invasion of the North occurred they would be found ready to take up arms against the North again.
The only plan to ward off danger from the South in that event was to break the spirit of the people utterly, to disarm them, free the negroes, and confiscate all their property, leaving them entirely subjugated and powerless, after which they would be ready for the war with Europe.

The President's programme prevailed of course, and it is now the programme of the war. It will be seen that the ideas of both these dignitaries are set upon saving themselves, and it appears that the South must be destroyed in order to save the North against the threatening power of Europe.
The South is a mere cat's-paw, to be conciliated or crushed as their relations with other nations may require.
Mr. Seward offers his conciliation not through any love of the South, but through his fears of Europe.
His magnanimity is stimulated by his alarm for his own Government.
Southern people know how to appreciate such magnanimity.
The above information comes from a prominent gentleman who had an interview with a member of the Kentucky delegation.

div3.head: "The Smiths."--John Smith
div3.p:
--plain John Smith — is not very high sounding; it does not suggest aristocracy; it is not the name of any hero in die-away novels, and yet is good, strong, and honest.
Transferred to other languages it seems to climb the ladder of respectability.
Thus in Latin it is Johannes Smithus; the Italian smoothes it off into Gloyanni Smith; the Spaniards render it Juan Smithus; the Dutchman adopt it as Hans Schmidt; the French flattens it out into Jean Smeets; and the Russian success and barks Jouloff Smittowaki.
When John Smith gets into the tea trade at Canton he becomes Jabon Shimmit; if he clambers about Mount Hecle the Icelanders say he is Jahne Smithson; if he trades among the Tuscaroras he becomes Ton Qua Smittia; in Poland he is known as Ivan Schmittiwelski; should he wander among the Welsh mountains they talk of Jason Schmidt; when he goes to Mexico he is booked as Jontil F'Smitti if of classic turn, he lingers among Greek ruins, he turns to Ion Smiktton; and in Turkey he is utterly disguised as Joe Seef.

Baltimore papers of the 29th ultimo have been received.
They furnish the annexed summary of news:

div4.head: Mosby after the sutlers.
div4.p: The Gazette gives the following account of Maj. Mosby's latest descent upon the sutlers:

On Sunday night last, Mosby and about two hundred of his command bivouacked near Langley's above the Chain bridge.
On Monday, they seized all the horses they could find, and appear to have succeeded in carrying them off without loss.
On Tuesday, having formed a junction with White's cavalry, and numbering in the aggregate — so at least we have it reported — some seven or eight hundred men, Mosby attacked at night a train of forty-four sutlers' wagons, between Centreville and Bull Run, and without meeting with much resistance, although the train was guarded by Federal soldiers, captured the whole of the wagons and their contents, nearly all the cavalry escort, together with a large number of Government horses and other property belonging to the Government and private individuals, to a very heavy amount.
Mosby was subsequently pursued, brought to bay, and wounded, but the probabilities are that he got off safely with his booty.

div4.head: From Missouri.
div4.p:
Quantrell's raid upon Lawrence, Kansas, seems to have provoked a war of extermination against the people of Northern Missouri.
The Gazette, in its summary of the telegraphic reports, says:

q.p:
An order has been issued from headquarters, at Kansas City, which, if carried out, will depopulate nearly the whole of the three counties in Missouri lying closest to the Kansas line.
The order directs all persons living within the limits specified, with certain exceptions, "to remove from their present places of residence within fifteen days, unless, in the meantime, they prove their loyalty to the satisfaction of the commanding officer."

div4.p:
On this proof being given, they will not even then be permitted to remain at their old homes, but may remove to any military station within that military district, "or to any part of Kansas, except the counties on the eastern border of the State." Those who do not so prove their loyalty are to depart further into the interior of Missouri, or elsewhere.
All the grain and hay of the loyal persons remaining in the field or under shelter, must, after the lapse of fifteen days from the date of this order, be taken to the nearest military station and turned over to the commanding officer.
All other grain and hay too remote from a military station to be brought in within the specified time will be destroyed.

div4.head: From Charleston.
div4.p:
An official dispatch from Gen. Gillmore, dated the 24th inst., announces the practical demolition of Fort Wagner, after a bombardment continued for seven successive days.
Gen. G. also states that he had succeeded at great labor and under a heavy fire from James Island in establishing batteries within effective range of the heart of the city, and has opened with them, after giving Gen. Beauregard due notice of his intention to do so.

From other sources we learn that the shells thrown into Charlesion were charged with Greek fire, "a peculiar compound of bitumen, raptha, and pitch of a most offensive odor, and possessing the property of burning either on the surface or under the water."

One other fact we learn from the Morris Island correspondence: The only gun of sufficient range to throw a shell into the city of Charleston was the three hundred pounder Parrott rifle; but this enormous piece of ordnance, after a few discharges, "accidentally burst, breaking off about a foot from the muzzle." This mishap has not only destroyed the accuracy of its fire, but has reduced its range by a mile and a half; so that until another gun of equal calibre can be invented no more shells can be thrown into Charleston.

div4.head: Reconnaissance to the Chickahominy.
div4.p: A telegram dated Fortress Monroe, August 26th says:

q.p: Major J. S. Stevenson, Lieut. Chambers, and sixty men of Roberts's 3d Pennsylvania artillery, left here Sunday night on the armed steamboat C. P. Smith, and reached the Chickahominy river Monday A. M., and proceeded about ten miles up, landing scouting parties at different points along the shores, destroying a number of small boats.

div4.p:
When about nine miles up the Chickahominy they met and attacked thirty rebel cavalrymen, belonging to Robinson's regiment.
The cavalry were repulsed — no one on our side injured.
They then shelled and destroyed the building used as headquarters by Col. Robinson.
They captured two men, and after obtaining from them all desired information, let them go. The expedition returned to Fortress Monroe this afternoon.

div3.head: Later from Europe.
div3.p: The steamship Hibernia, at Cape Race, brings European advices to the 19th ult. The news is unimportant:
The London Daily News (Abolition) eulogizes Lincoln's proclamation announcing a system of retaliation in reference to the treatment of negroes as prisoners of war.

La France asserts that the acceptance of the Mexican crown by the Archduke Maximilian is not doubted, and believes that negotiations have been entered into to obtain the adhesion of England.
La France also says that the present Government of Mexico will administer its affairs for one year to organize the country.
Garibaldi has published a letter, addressed to "Abraham Lincoln, Liberator of the Slaves in the Republic of America." He compares him to the "Son of God, and John Brown ! "
Liverpool, Aug. 19.--Cotton. --Sales to-day 10,000 bales, market closing buoyant and upward.
Breadstuffs closed with a downward tendency.
London, Aug. 19.--Consols closed at 93a 93½

div3.head: The U. S. Adjutant-General in the West.
div3.p:
--The movements of the Federal armies in the West are in full progress.
A letter from Morton, Miss., to the Atlanta Appeal, speaking of them, says:

q.p:
It is a fact worthy of note that General Thomas, the Adjutant-General of the United States forces, arrived at Memphis week before last.
I attach more importance to this event than seems to be given it elsewhere.
This same Thomas came West immediately after Grant's several repulses in his approach to Vicksburg, and it was studiously given out that the Adjutant-General of Lincoln was present for the purpose of organizing the negro forces.
Instead of this, he brought out from Washington with him the Vicksburg back-door programme for Grant, carefully arranged by Halleck and others.
This mode of attack never suggested itself to Grant, and would have been unattempted except by superior genius.
We have now Thomas in the West once more, and with his presence from Washington comes in all probability the draught of a new campaign.
Let us be on the watch.
An Adjutant-General of a powerful nation does not leave his post from idle curiosity, or for pleasure.
It is not improbable that the Grenada raid for the destruction of our railroad stock came from or through him; but this is only a picket skirmish to the battle chart which he brings for Grant.

div3.head: Deaths at David's Island.
div3.p: --From a returned prisoner we learn that the total number of deaths among Confederate prisoners confined at David's Island, New York, up to August 24th, was 111. S. C. Redman, First Lieutenant company C. 40th Va., died August 2d; and J. R. Emerson, First Lieutenant company E. 26th North Carolina, died August 11th.

div3.head: Meeting of 48th Regt' N. C. Troops.

opener.dateline:
Hdq'rs 48th Reg't N. C. Troops.
near Fredericksb'g, Va., Aug. 15th, 1863.

div4.p: at a meeting of the officers and soldiers of the 48th N. C. Regiment, held in camp near Fredericksburg, Va., on the 15th day of August, 1863, on motion of Col. R. C. Hill Dr. B. Chears was appointed Chairman, and privates A. A. Watson, of Co. B, and J. H. McCoy, of Co. A, were appointed Secretaries.

the object of the meeting being explained in a patriotic and spirited address by Col. Hill, on motion of the Chairman the following officers and soldiers were appointed a committee to draft resolutions expressive of the meeting:

Capts L C Hanes, a Q M; W H Jones, Co. G; L a W Turner, Co. A; J M Mabry, Co. B; J F Heltman, Co. H; Lieut M D Clegg, Co. D; Serg'ts Jas Lewry, Co. A; J W Lambeth, Co. H; Corp'l Joseph Guthrie, Co. G; privates D W Conrad, Co. B; a B McKay, Co. C; Jos P Horn, Co. E; J Rowell, Co. E Joe Sailor, Co. K; who reported through the Chairman the following preamble and resolutions:

Whereas, we have heard with much mortification that public meetings have been held in some counties of North Carolina, in which resolutions have been passed taking a gloomy and discouraging view of our existing controversy with the North, calling for a general convention of all the States, and some even favoring a reconstruction of the old and in one county to of the tax in kind imposed by the Confederate Government; and Whereas, we have seen these resolutions published in the North Carolina Standard--a paper having an extensive circulation in said State--not only without a disapproving comment of the editor, but with evident marks of approbation; and Whereas such action, if suffered to pass without rebuke, will place the good and patriotic old North State in a false position, both at home and abroad, and misrepresent her real character: Therefore be it.

list.item: 1. Resolved, That we, the citizen soldiers of North Carolina, in the 48th regiment N. C. troops, disclaim and denounce the sentiments expressed in the said resolutions, so far as they represent the hopelessness of our controversy, the policy of a general convention of the States and the reconstruction of the old Union, and the resistance of paying taxes, as unwise and unpatriotic, calculated to produce disaffection and dissention, and bring contempt upon our loyal State among our Southern sister States; that it gives aid and comfort to our enemies, and blasts our reasonable expectations of being recognized by European powers as a free, united, and independent people.

2. Resolved, That if these prophets of evil have not the virtue and manliness to uphold the hands of the heroic defenders of our country by aiding them with encouraging words and action, that they ought to exercise the virtue and patience of forbearance; and as they are inactive for good, they should not be so eager and industrious for evil; that we believe that if they would be but half so active in aiding as they have been in depressing our cause, our contest would not only not be hopeless, but would certainly be successful, as it will be, with or without their aid,

3. Resolved, That we are opposed to all parties, meetings, and conventions, that propose peace upon any other terms than that of a final and eternal separation of the Confederate States with the United States.
We spurn with scorn and contempt the propositions of submission and reconstruction as cowardly and pusillanimous, as the act would be disgraceful in the eyes of the world, who have been forced to look upon us with wonder and admiration.

4. Resolved, That we have a peace party whose banners have waved in proud triumph over many fields of carnage and blood, filling our vile enemies with consternation and fear, and whose platform is broad enough to accommodate every true and patriotic citizen of the Confederate States.
To a firm, unyielding and hearty support of this patriotic party we earnestly call every citizen of the old North State, as the only sure means of securing to us a speedy and honorable peace.

5. Resolved, That while we view with painful emotions our ruined towns and villages — our smouldering homes and wasted property — but infinitely worse than all this is the voice of the blood of thousands of North Carolina's best and noblest sons crying for vengeance from the crimson hills and dales of Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and other States.
When we see the tears of thousands of bereaved mothers, from the seaboard to the mountains, mourning the untimely fall of their noble sons by the relentless hands of the ruffian foe, we are the more determined to be free, and to avenge our brothers' blood; the Lord being our helper, to whom vengeance belongeth.
We are not willing that all this shall pass for nought — we are not willing to submit to the iron rule of Yankees who declare by word and deed the negro to be our equals.

6. Resolved, That in our late reverses we perceive no cause for despondency; but, so far from considering our cause hopeless, we feel the strongest faith in the certainty of our speedy success; that we have an abiding confidence that there are more for us than there are against us; for we believe that God is with us — that His guardian angel is encamped about our hosts — and, therefore, that our ultimate victory is sure.

7. Resolved, That the publication of such resolutions as is above referred to, in journals so extensively circulated as the North Carolina Standard, without a disapproving comment, and with apparent endorsement, is promotive of evil only, and evil continually, and merits the stern rebuke of every lover of our cause, and every one of the patriotic sons of North Carolina, who are aspersed and misrepresented by such unjust and cowardly insinuations upon their loyalty, their good faith, and courage.

8. Resolved, That we feel the utmost confidence in the honesty, ability, integrity, and patriotism of President Davis, Gen. Lee, and Gov. Vance, and feel assured that the destinies of the Republic, the army, and the State of North Carolina, are safe in their hands.
9. Resolved, That the proceedings of this meeting be published in the Richmond Dispatch, and that the other Richmond and North Carolina papers be requested to copy.

div4.p: After the reading of the above preamble and resolutions to a very full meeting, Lt. Col. S. H. Walkup being called upon responded in a brief but cheering speech, whereupon the preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted by acclamation.
div4.closer:
B. Chears, Chairman.
Jos. H. McCoy, Co. A, Sec's.
A. A. Watson, Co. B; Sec's.

div3.head: Those Charming hats.
div3.p: --Ladies who persist in wearing those "charming hats" will be delighted with the following extract from the Paris correspondent of the New York Express:

q.p:
The hat, in all its varieties, is worn at all the watering places, and in traveling.
It is inadmissible in Paris, except upon "misses" and dimly English women. The milliners say it is not comme it fact to wear a bonnet in traveling, and that the hat may be worn anywhere out of Paris by the most difficult of ladies.

div3.head: Impressing horses.
div3.p:
--The Bristol Advocate says that orders from headquarters have been issued for the impressment of six or eight thousand horses from Southwestern Virginia and East Tennessee.
Some two hundred were impressed at Abingdon, Va., on last Monday.

div3.head: Mosby wounded.
div3.p:
--Col. Mosby, the daring and brilliant cavalry chieftain, was severely, though not dangerously, wounded in a skirmish with the enemy near Fredericksburg.
He was shot in two places, the leg and groin.
He is now at the residence of his fat her, A. D. Mosby, in Amherst.

div3.head: Gold Tumbling.
div3.p:
--The Confederacy says there has been a heavy decline in the price of gold, sterling exchange, and bank notes, in Atlanta, for a few days past.
Gold has declined about four hundred per cent., and is still falling.
There are thirty thousand troops, according to the New York Herald, stationed in and around that city to enforce the draft.

div3.head: The debt of the United States--Interesting Statistics.
div3.p: Among the bold assumptions of the present head of the Treasury Department is the following, contained in his report to Congress, and which is reiterated by the radical press on every side.
"The circulation of the United States notes constitutes practically a loan from the people to their Government, without interest."

The object of this piece of charla is to induce the idea that two thousand millions of debt is no material damage to the people.
There is, however, no person so thoughtless or reckless in his daily expenditures that he does not know how much higher are all pieces of goods he is obliged to buy, in consequence of the use of paper money.
Even every servant girl who remit her little savings out of her hard earnings to relieve the wants of some dear friend at home, knows that she must pay for one pound six and seven dollars instead of five dollars, and workmen are compelled to strike for higher wages in order to live.
The Treasury Department is not exempt from the same universal law; all the pay of ministers and others remitted abroad, all purchases of material and supplies for the Government, are subjected to the same charge.

The expenditure of the past year has been eight hundred millions of dollars, of which one hundred millions of dollars, of which one hundred millions of dollars was fixed sums, like soldiers' pay, &c., The remaining even hundred millions was for supplies and contracts at varying paper prices, the average advance on which has been 40 per cent, in consequence of this "paper without interest"--in other words, the Treasury has paid seven hundred millions of dollars for what at specie prices would have cost but five hundred millions of dollars.
The differences, two hundred millions of dollars, is "the interest," paid indirectly upon the paper money issues.
The official statement of the debt, with interest, July 1, 1863, was as follows:

Thus the amount of interest already paid by the Treasury is twenty-two per cent., and the rate will increase in proportion to the extension of the paper money.
If the paper money is ever paid at all it must be by funding it, and that cannot be done at a rate less than six per cent. If we assume that it may be done at that rate, the annual charge with the sinking fund will be seventy-seven millions of dollars per annum.
This debt has been contracted by twenty States, which will be required to pay it, since, as the war is declared to be one of extermination, the "exterminated States" will not be able to pay. Their means of paying in any event is crushed in proportion to the devastation committed.
The twenty millions of Northern people must therefore pay the debt; and it compares with the British and French debt as follows:
the debt is now nearly equal to the British debt, and increases at the rate of more than two million per day, without prospect of an end. The following are the official statements of the public debt:

Thus every successive six months the daily increase is greater.
This does not include the large and unadjusted claims due July 1, and which will swell the aggregate to $130,000,000, but simply the paper outstanding.
It will be borne in mind, also, the sum mentioned is not the whole expenditure, but simply that portion met by promises to pay. We may now see what portion of this vast debt, already equal in weight to the British debt, and increasing at the rate two million and a half per day, falls upon New York.
The population of the State is 3,880,735.
its proportion or the debt is $210,000,000, and, with State and city debts, is as follows.

the annual interest on the debt is $4.61 per head, exceeding that of the British debt, and the sum of the debt equals the whole assessed personal property in the State, and the increase per day for New York debt is $500,000 ! the proportion for the city is as follows:

The average interest is $6.75 per head per annum, or $2.25 per head more than the British debt.
The personal estate assessed is already mortgaged, and the obligations goes on to increase against the city at the rate of $100,000 per day, while the business of the city is crushed, and its productive population demand for army service to subjugate and exterminate New York's chief commercial dependence, the great Agricultural South.
When will the increase of debt stop?
When will pay day commence?
It will be remembered that up to this time no one has been asked to pay. The debt has only been created, and as long as that process goes on the pressure will not be felt.
When that process stops, and the obligations now being issued appear for payment, the real distress will come.
The mortgages on New York property have been paid to New England army contractors.
In a year they will have all the property in New York, and the mortgages will be foreclosed with relentless vigor.

div3.head: The Alabama Legislature.
div3.p: --A letter from Montgomery, dated 21st instant, says:

q.p:
Yesterday both Houses got fairly at work and remained in session from 9 A. M. until 2 o'clock P. M. The principal part of the day in the House, however, was occupied in the discussion of the report of the Select Committee upon the Senate resolution censuring Generals Pemberton and Holmes.
The committee in its report entirety ignored the Senate resolutions, so far as they in the least reflected upon these Generals — in fact the names of these officers do not occur in the report of the committee.
The House after considerable unnecessary discussion, adopted the report, as it came from the committee, by the decisive vote of 85 to 5.
In this respect the House displayed its wisdom, and manifested a degree of conservatism which does not exist in the Senate.

div3.p: Mr. N. H. R. Dawson, of Dallas, offered a resolution in the House, which was referred to the Committee on Confederate Relations, instructing the committee to inquire into the expediency of reporting a law to place negroes in the Confederate service to act in the capacity of cooks and teamsters.

Another resolution was offered in the House, and referred to the same committee, requesting the committee to ascertain and report upon the expediency of the passage of a resolution instructing our Senators and members of Congress to use their influence in procuring the passage of a law by Congress placing in the Confederate service one hundred thousand able- bodied negroes.
This is a subject of great importance, and now occupying much of the public mind.
It is now admitted that the enemy are using extensively this class of people in their regular armies.
It is true, we do not know to what extent the negroes have proven available as fighting material; but this we do know, that they have been used, and in some instances successfully so. The Yankee Government is encouraging this element of military strength.
If this be so, it seems to be the plain duty of this Government to enlist the negroes, who would otherwise fall into the hands of the Abolitionists, and be used against us.
Henry Timred, the post, of South Carolina, has just been elected Secretary and of the Board of Supervisors of the High school of Charleston.

div3.head: Military execution at New Orleans
div3.p:
--The True Delta of a recent date gives an account of the execution of Francis Scott, found guilty and condemned to suffer death, on a charge of having will fully and maliciously murdered Maj. J. D. Bullen, of the 28th Massachusetts regiment, on the 5th of July, at Fort Butler, Donaldsonville, who was in command at that post.
The murder was committed while Scott was on duty.
Some difficulty occurred between the Major and Scott, when the latter raised his musket and fired at the Major, wounding hire in the wrist and body.
The officer died a few days subsequent, from the effects of the wound in the body.
Scott was tried by Court martial, convicted, and sentenced to death.
The following is the True Delta's report of the last remarks of the condemned man:

Fellow-soldiers: I am about to die for killing Major Bullen.
I did kill him, and would do the same thing over under similar circumstances.
I had never met him before that day. My company had come down from Port Hudson to Donaldsonville, and we stopped there in the fort.
That evening Major Bullen came to the breast work and told my Captain that he must the breast works, as he was going his detachment.
The Captain was under marching orders, and he did not think it right that he should be left there.--The Major replied: "You must obey orders, sir, and I order you to remain here." Without intending anything wrong, I happened to say: "Well, Captain, we'll take care of these breastworks, and protect his nine-months' men from the enemy." At which the Major turned upon me, and some words passed between us, when he drew his revolver and aimed it at me. My musket was at an order, and I brought it to a ready, and before he could fire I fired at him. I shot him through the wrist and in the body.
I killed him, and am content to die for it.--Had he killed me, there would have been nothing done.
An officer is never punished for killing a soldier.
I hold no malice against any one, and freely forgive everybody, as I hope all will forgive me. Had General Banks a thousand men like me they would be worth more than all the conscripts that the State of Maine can send to the field." As he closed these remarks he dropped upon his knees, and, looking towards the detail, said: "I am ready."

Scott was born in the county of Monaghan, Ireland, and was about thirty years of age. He had served an enlistment of five years in the Fifth U. S. infantry of the of the old line.
At the time the rebellion broke out he was residing in New Orleans, and had been employed as a deck hand on the river.
He was well known in the vicinity of St. Mary's market, where he used to pass his time when ashore, and had been in several drunken rows in that not over quiet neighborhood.
He enlisted in the rebel army, being out of employment and unable to find any other means of gaining a livelihood, and served in the 1st La. regular artillery, at Fort Jackson, until the capture of that stronghold, when he was taken prisoner and paroled.
He subsequently preferred taking the oath to being exchanged and enlisted in the 1st La. (Union) regiment.

div3.head: A dead man comes to life.
div3.p: --The New Orleans. Era, of the 15th ultimo, chronicles a singular occurrence, as follows:

q.p:
We yesterday reported that Mr. Henry Myers, residing on Clouet street, had been killed by lightning.
An inquest had been held off the body and life pronounced extinct.
Yesterday every preparation had been made for his funeral, his friends had assembled, the body been duty coffined, the relatives had put on mourning, the hearse and the priest arrived, and the coffin was about to be closed up, when the arms of the corpse were observed to move, and very soon, wonderful to relate ! the dead man sat bolt up right in his coffin, and, after surveying the scene for a few moments, inquired the cause of all the gloomy preparations he saw going on. The Joy of his weeping wife and little ones cap be imagined when they found the dead had actually returned to life, and the house of mourning was soon turned into a house of rejoicing — the funeral into a feast.
The electric shock had suspended animation for over twenty-four hours--so perfectly as to deceive even the Coroner, the man's wife, and all his friends.

div3.head: Drunk by wards.
div3.p:
--A private letter from Philadelphia says: "--Our city is drunk-- "not all at once, but a ward at a time.
We draft by wards, and those who are drafted have to stand treat on account of their misfortune, and those who escape have to stand treat on account of their good fortune.
The result is we get inebriated by wards, and Philadelphia goes to bed drunk."

div3.head: Death of a musician
div3.p:
--The well known musician.
Christopher Vollandt, died on Monday morning, at his residence in this city, after a brief illness of for over deceased had been leader of the Band.
He was from Baltimore, where for many years, be led the known by his own name for beginning of the present struggle for independence he left the Monumental City, bringing with him his musical companions, who, with their leader, attached themselves, to the forces of Col. John Magruder, where they served a year.
The deceased was as generally and favorably known throughout the limits of the late Union as he was in Baltimore, the place of his residence.
In other and better times the habitues of the Greenbrier White Sulphur Springs will miss the pleasant echoes of his magic bugle, which were wont in former years to reverberate in that locality every summer.
He was a composer of rare excellence, and as a leader had few equals.

div3.head: Heavy hand.
div3.p:
--About 9 o'clock yesterday morning, while watchmen Troner and Branch were making their round of Cary street, near 6th, they saw a negro fellow watching them, and, suspecting that all was not right, took such a position in the shade as enabled them to see what was going on. A bout 5 o'clock they saw two negroes come out of Mr. Freclaud's back yard, and shortly there after saw them reading a wagon with a variety of articles.
When the wagon moved off they pursued it, and, stopping it on 5th street, found that it contained six sides of leather, one bag of coffee, and one bolt, of cloth — the whole valued at $1,000. They at once took into custody Mead, slave to W. P. Strother, and Sam, (the driver.) slave to Geo. W. Randolph, and, as neither of them could satisfy the watchmen of their honesty of purpose in having the goods, they were lodged in the cage.
The watchmen then made inquiries in the neighborhood, and found that the goods had been stolen from the C. S. Government ordnance stone, which is kept in Mr. Freeland's factory.
Sam and Mead were heard before the Mayor and sent on for final trial at the next term of the Hustings Court.
Another of the party is yet at large.

div3.head: Outrageous.
div3.p:
--Our military authorities should take proper steps to put an end to the continual outrages perpetrated on market men at night on the various roads leading to this city.
Scarcely a morning passes that complaints' are not heard of market carts being robbed the night before of their melons and vegetables by men professing to be soldiers.
Many of the carts are driven by negroes, who can offer no resistance to the robbers.
To such an extent has these depredations been permitted that some of the countrymen have stopped their carts, and declare they will supply the city no more till they have some protection for their produce when on its way to market.
A military patrol around the camps would prevent these annoyances.

div3.head: Scape Goats.
div3.p:
--The fact that there are some had men wearing Confederate uniforms, and that their officers exercise no sort of control over them, gives every villain in the land an admirable opportunity to lay his sins on the poor soldiers.
If a ben roost is robbed, a corn field lessened of lie ears, a favorite horse ridden off a smoke house broken into, or a row created, the offence is at once charged to the soldiers.
People forget that every army has its followers — its rifle corps — and that these followers prey alike on the living and the dead.
Their numbers increase at every battle, for all skulkers join them — and whom a fight is imminent, or duty is to be performed, they scatter throughout the country and instantly devastate it. As long as these pests are tolerated the country may expect to suffer in every conceivable manner.

div3.head: Good Investment.
div3.p:
--The stockholders of the Traders' Bank of Richmond are reminded that they have but three days more left them to take the new stock at the price fixed by the Board.
After the third instant the public will be allowed to invest in sums to suit their surplus capital.
The Traders' Bank, thus far, has been an exceedingly successful institution, always paying large dividends.
Its increases, of capital will add to its means of profit, and the stock holders, of all others, are the right men to have the benefit of that.
increase.

div3.head: Prison record.
div3.p: --The only case booked at Castle Thunder worth mentioning is that of Frank Livingston, charged with being generally a bad character, who is to be sent before Judge Halyburton this morning.
A white woman, named Ann Reilly, was committed to the cage yesterday afternoon, on the charge of stealing one silver watch, the property of Parmelia Robertson.

div3.head: Continued.
div3.p:
--George W. Marray was again before the Mayor yesterday to answer the charge of receiving a coat and a pair of pants stolen from Mrs. Hatcher, knowing the same to have been stolen.
Murray proved that he purchased the clothes of two soldiers; but the Mayor declined to conclude the case because of the absence of a witness for the Commonwealth.
The prisoner was admitted to bail for his appearance.

div3.head: Not guilty.
div3.p:
--Patrick Larkin and his wife, Mary, charged with assaulting, heating, and robbing Edward Kane, a soldier, were again before the Mayor yesterday for examination.
After hearing a number of witnesses the Mayor concluded that Kane was intoxicated when he lost his money, and that the Larkins were not the robbers.
He therefore discharged them.

div3.head: Bad Liqueur
div3.p:
and a large quantity of it, made James Dixon so very disorderly in the streets last Sunday that he was locked up to cool off. Yesterday Jim was before the Mayor, and after a hearing was committed to prison in default of bail for his future good conduct.
Jim is quiet and orderly when sober, but a few spirituous inhalations are sure to get him into trouble.

div3.head: Sent to the Grand Jury.
div3.p:
--Wm. Bethel, arrested on a warrant for assaulting and boating Michael Shea without provocation, appeared before the Mayor yesterday.
His Honor, after hearing the evidence, held the accused do bail for his good behavior, at sent him on to the next Grand Jury term the Hustings Court to answer an indictment.

div3.head: House breaking.
div3.p: --Jordana Mayo, a free ingress of notorious bad character, has her arrested and imprisoned for breaking Robert Crane's house and straining a death bed. When brought before the Mayor, Jordana declared her ability to prove her and was therefore given until this morning to have her witnesses looked up.

div3.head: Local defence.
div3.p: --A case affecting Capt. Hayward's, and other companies organized for home defence, will be brought before Judge Halyburton this morning for his whether they shall be subject to or be retained within the surroundings of the city.

div3.head: Shooting.
div3.p:
--William E. Travis, Charged with shooting his wife Ellen, was before the Mayor yesterday, but owing to the absence of Mrs. T. the was postponed till to- morrow.
Travis expects to by his wife that the shooting was purely accidental.

div3.head: The Confederate reserves.
div3.p: --In the last extremity, should the Confederate Government be no longer able to cope with the enemy, even by bringing into the field all the men between eighteen and forty-five and organizing into savage guerillas all the gay young gentlemen between forty-five and sixty, there are large bodies of reserves, who, if they can be made to face the music, and to put their peculiar powers in full play upon the enemy, would tear down the United States Government, or any other Government under the sun, in twenty-four hours. Taking as the measure of their capacity for mischief the amount of harm they have done their own country, we feel safe in asserting that they can be made the most deadly enginery yet employed in modern warfare.

The first class, to be put immediately in the field, with no privilege of obtaining substitutes, should be the speculators, extortioners, and every other man who has grown rich out of the wants of his suffering fellow-men, and while his country was bleeding at every pore. --Upon the approved principles of setting a rogue to catch a rogue and fighting the devil with fire, we can conceive no better policy than pitting these home-made Yankees against the foreign article.--Such a charge as they would make, judging by their financial achievements, has not yet been equalled in this war. Even Pickett's division at Gettysburg could not rival this legion of pickpockets.
The Yankees already mortified to death by the superior knavery of the Southern extortioners could not look them for a moment in the face.
Instead of handling their muskets, they would be buttoning their pockets, and seeking safety for that which they hold dearer than life in a frantic retreat.
If the Government knows what it is about it will at once order the speculators and extortioners to the fore-front of the battle.

Another large army might be made up of the croakers, who stay at home whilst brave men are in the field, and, whilst they will not fight themselves, do their best, unintentionally perhaps, to discourage those who do. These sad dogs should at once become the prey of the Confederate dog-catchers.
They should be made to turn to some useful account their lugubrious wailings and tribulations.
Strong bodies of them posted of dark nights in the immediate neighborhood of the enemy, should be set to croaking like the combined orchestras of the Dismal Swamp.
No mortal of ordinary flesh and blood could stand the doleful sound.
The spirits of the honest would sink before that vast, infernal chorus of the hopeless damned, which has already half demoralized and paralyzed much bolder men than the Yankees,--the brave soldiers of the Southern Confederacy.

And, finally, a "forlorn hope" might be organized for the Southern army in the stout and stalwart young men who are crowding the streets of all our principal towns, some of them sporting uniforms which are a sham and an imposture, inasmuch as they never yet smelt of gunpowder, and all fattening themselves in various positions at the public crib, whilst the sons of other men, who have no more at stake than themselves in the success of the cause, are serving, often as privates, in the field.
The whole band of these luxurious swine should be made to pay for their keeping, and those of them who do the ornamental in the military way compelled to flourish their fine feathers in the company of those valiant war hawks of the battle-field whose fierce eyes and red talons are the only uniform that fighting birds affect.
A gentleman lately from Mississippi informs us that at every stopping place on his way to Richmond he saw such numbers of active young men that he wondered where the Confederate Generals had drawn their armies.
There is a third corps which we recommend to the attention of the Government.
The shams, humbugs, skulkers, and selfish lovers of their ease, who permit braver and better men than themselves to bleed and die for the common cause, should be compelled to perform their part, and there are enough of them to outnumber the Yankees on every battle-field.
The most stringent measures should be adopted to place men of the military age, not disqualified physically, in military positions in actual field duties, where they may fill up, as far as may be, the thinned ranks of patriot heroes whose shoe latches they are not worthy to unloose.

div3.head: An ignoble Race.
div3.p:
--That the Yankees are an ignoble race, devoid alike of magnanimity and humanity is shown in this war. Their cruelties, brutalities and thieving show their want of humanity and their rapacity.
Their pusillanimity is glaringly exhibited in the expedients they employ to subjugate us. They boasted at the beginning of the war that they could soon whip us and put us under subjection to Lincoln — it was a mere matter of arithmetical estimate: They were eighteen million of people and we only eight; and as eighteen million could easily whip eight, of course we would soon be brought back to acknowledge our task-masters.
Beginning with this great numerical disparity in their favor, they now boast that it is greater, they claiming twenty million, and allowing us only six! Besides this immense advantage in numbers they had the entire navy and army of the United States, all the powder mills, and nearly all the manufactories of arms and of everything necessary to equip an army and wage war — while we had hardly anything, and they blockaded our ports to keep us from getting anything from abroad.

But notwithstanding this — this "all-the-world to nothing," as it were, in their favor and against the South--we have seen the Yankees ever since the war began canvassing Europe to get men to help them to whip the South!
This Goliath has been running over the world begging everybody to help him whip the little David of the South!
This Northern monster offered Garibaldi large bribes to bring over an army from Italy to help him — he has filled the continent and Great Britain with agents to induce men to emigrate to the United States, and thus succeeded in increasing the number of deluded emigrants into the North to 90,000 the present year — some 40,000 in excess over the last.
Yet, not satisfied with thus swelling his invading hordes beyond anything in modern times, his pusillanimity and meanness has culminated in the extreme act of disgrace and barbarism of arming the black slaves of he South against their musters! at act of baseness the conquerors of barbarous ages were too proud to be guilty of, even where the slaves were white!

Was ever there a national example so ignominious?
Could there be an exhibition of national character so dishonorable, so pusillanimous, so execrable?
It is disgraceful to humanity, and must brand the people of the North and their descendants for ages to come with infamy.
Is it possible that the South can be conquered by so base a foe?
From the Potomac to the Rio Grande there can be but one universal shout of — No, never!

div3.head: North Carolina.
div3.p:
--We publish to-day the proceedings of the 48th North Carolina regiment denouncing the course of the Raleigh Standard.
The gallant sons of Carolina in the field have with great unanimity relieved themselves of whatever odium might attach to the public character from the fact that a newspaper so unsound as the Standard is published at the seat of Government.
We refer now to these proceedings of the 48th regiment because it is composed of men from that part of the State where it is supposed the obnoxious and insidious teachings of the paper in question have found most favor.
It consists of four companies from Union county, two from Davidson, and one each from Moore, Iredell, Forsythe, and Cheatham.
Seven-eighths of the regiment were in party times Old-Line Whigs.
The Lieut.-Colonel was a prominent member of the same party, as were also the Major and all the Captains, save two.
No reflection is, of course, meant upon the Whigs of North Carolina, who have proved their valor in the field and their fidelity to the South in every situation since the war began.
They were, however, especially in the region above referred to, strong Union men to a late period of the sectional agitation which terminated in the dissolution of the Union.
But when the time came they took the positions of true and loyal men, and have honored their State and the South by their gallant deeds.
The entire regiment, we are informed, was present, and took part in these proceedings.
It is commanded by Col. Hill, a native of North Carolina, formerly of the U. S. army, and an able and brave officer.

div3.head: Guerillas.
div3.p:
--The savage and inhuman measures adopted by the Yankees to put down guerilla warfare prove that this mode of defending a country otherwise unprotected is more annoying and more dreaded by them than any other.
Like the brutal threats fulminated against privateers, their ferocity against guerillas shows their vulnerable points, and teaches us how and where to strike.
Let the guerilla system be thoroughly carried out, and if the barbarians retaliate in the mode they threaten, let the guerillas, without waiting for orders, exact an eye for an eye and a life for a life.
We shall soon see, in that event, which will soonest tire of the black flag, and be ready to return to the laws of civilized warfare.

div3.p:
--Ran away from us subscriber, about the 25th of July last, a boy, named Major.
He is a bright mulatto, about 21 years old; 5 feet 8½ inches high, and is a very likely boy. He was raised near Chesterfield C H, Va., and is supposed that be is now in that neighborhood, and probably harbored by some person.
I will give a reward of $150 for his apprehension and confinement that I get him again, and $200 for the conviction of any person harboring him.

50 dollars reward will be paid for the apprehension of a negro man, named Ben. The said negro is about 22 years of age; dark complexion full suit of hair, prominent front teeth, with peculiar white splotches on them.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the recovery of a negro boy, 12 years old, black, dull looking, and slow spoken, named George, with a scar on one arm and hand, from a burn.
He left on last Monday, after the dog-catchers, a house on 24 street.
He is supposed to be lost or stolen.
Information can be left at the Dispatch office, or by addressing me through Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--About 18 months ago, my servant Rose, (sometimes called Rosette Page) She is tail; spare; black; bad teeth; has a peculiar shaped head; aged about 45; she is a good cook, washer, and ironer, and I have no doubt she is employed in the city as such.
I hereby forewarn all persons from employing said slave as the law shall be rigidly enforced.
A liberal reward will be paid for her delivery to the subscriber, on Clay, between 2d and 3d sts.

div3.head: One hundred dollars
div3.p:
Reward will be paid for the delivery of my man William, a black smith by trade, who ranaway from Messrs. Haxall A Crenshaw about the 1st August, 1863.
Said man is about 6 feet high, 21 years old, brown complexion, good looking, and intelligent.
div3.closer:
Wm P. Smith.
For George Duggins. au 28--6t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension of Frank, the property of W Crenshaw.
He is of dark brown color, about five feet nine inches in height, has several white spots about his face, and is 25 to 27 years old. Frank was seen at the Central depot Sunday evening, 23d inst, when the cars arrived.
